item.title: Six Killed in Shooting Rampage in Saudi Arabia
item.description: The attacker opened fire in a building in southern Saudi Arabia. The Interior Ministry described it a “criminal” act, suggested it was unrelated to terrorism.
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD

item.title: NATO Will Send Ships to Aegean Sea to Deter Human Trafficking
item.description: The alliance’s secretary general said surveillance of the Turkey-Syria border would also be enhanced to monitor the activities of smugglers.
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL S. SCHMIDT and SEWELL CHAN
item.media:description: Defense Minister Michael Fallon of Britain, left, Secretary General Jens Stoltenberg of NATO, second left, and the American defense secretary, Ashton B. Carter, right, at a meeting in NATO’s headquarters in Brussels on Thursday.

item.title: Google Will Further Block Some European Search Results
item.description: To fend off privacy complaints, the search giant will block access to certain links from all of its search sites when used from the European Union.
item.dc:creator: MARK SCOTT
item.media:description: Despite Google’s renewed efforts to appease European privacy concerns, it remains unclear whether the company’s actions will be enough to head off the continuing legal disputes from Europe’s national data protection authorities.

item.title: Scanning Borders, Israel Surveys New Reality of Tunnels and Terror
item.description: It is more clear than ever that nonstate actors with sophisticated weapons and technology have replaced the threat to Israel from regular Arab armies.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Marc Israel Sellem
item.media:description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, center, toured a new section of fence along the border with Jordan, near Eilat, in southern Israel, on Tuesday.

item.title: No ‘P’ in Arabic Means No Palestine, Israeli Lawmaker Says
item.description: Anat Berko, a lawmaker from the governing Likud Party, drew ridicule after saying in a parliamentary debate that Palestine was a “borrowed term.”
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: 52 Inmates Killed in Mexican Prison Amid Riot and Fire
item.description: What began as a fight between two inmates escalated into a deadly riot in a penitentiary in the northern Mexico city of Monterrey.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETH MALKIN
item.media:description: People waited for news outside Topo Chico Prison in Monterrey, Mexico, on Thursday.

item.title: Nigeria Vexed by Boko Haram’s Use of Women as Suicide Bombers
item.description: Three girls sent by Boko Haram this week to attack a camp for those seeking to escape violence revealed a weakness in defenses against the militants.
item.dc:creator: DIONNE SEARCEY
item.media:description: The government-run camp at Dikwa, where about 52,000 people are being sheltered, most of them women and girls. Food is sparse there, and sanitation issues are growing.

item.title: Trial of Reinhold Hanning, Ex-Auschwitz Guard, Opens in Germany
item.description: The 94-year-old former Nazi is charged with being an accessory to the murder of at least 170,000 people who died at the camp in Poland.
item.dc:creator: MELISSA EDDY
item.media:description: Reinhold Hanning, center, a former guard at Auschwitz, in court in Detmold, Germany, on Thursday.

item.title: Indian Soldier Rescued After Siachen Avalanche Dies
item.description: He was buried for five days under 35 feet of ice on the Siachen Glacier, where Indian and Pakistani troops face one another at high elevations.
item.dc:creator: HARI KUMAR

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Don’t Forget Darfur
item.description: A reckless new military offensive by the Sudanese regime threatens another humanitarian disaster in the region.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: ERIC REEVES

item.title: State TV: Teacher Shoots Dead 6 Colleagues in Saudi Arabia
item.description: A teacher in southern Saudi Arabia opened fire on colleagues Thursday, killing at least six people and wounding two, state television reported.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: British Police Chief Says Sexual Abuse Complaints May Face More Skepticism
item.description: After embarrassing revelations related to child abuse inquiries, the authorities may no longer be encouraged to believe every complaint, he said.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER
item.media:description: Sir Bernard Hogan-Howe, Metropolitan Police Commissioner, in January.

item.title: Taiwanese City Moves Against Builder’s Holdings After Earthquake
item.description: Tainan has told local government agencies to monitor the 30 real estate holdings to prevent their sale in the event the victims’ families want to sue.
item.dc:creator: KEITH BRADSHER

item.title: North Korea to Freeze South’s Assets at Kaesong Industrial Park
item.description: The North issued a blizzard of retaliatory actions after South Korea said it would close the park.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN
item.media:description: Businessmen waiting at an immigration checkpoint in Paju, South Korea, on Thursday to re-enter the Kaesong joint industrial zone for their belongings.

item.title: School Bus Crash in Western France Kills 6 Students
item.description: The bus and a heavy truck collided at 7:15 a.m. in Rochefort, as the two vehicles passed each other on the road.
item.dc:creator: AURELIEN BREEDEN
item.media:description: The wreckage of a school bus after it and a truck collided in Rochefort, France, on Thursday.

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Britain, Better-off Out of Europe
item.description: As a referendum on membership looms, support for “Brexit” is growing.
item.dc:creator: LOUISE MENSCH

item.title: Santa Ana Zegache Journal: Oaxaca’s Native Maize Embraced by Top Chefs in U.S. and Europe
item.description: Mexico’s traditional corn was fading away, but it is now being bought in bulk to satisfy the appetites of fine diners.
item.category: International Maize and Wheat Improvement Center
item.dc:creator: VICTORIA BURNETT
item.media:credit: Rodrigo Cruz for The New York Times
item.media:description: María Juana, 22, prepared corn tortillas at a restaurant in Oaxaca, Mexico. An overseas taste for high-quality Mexican food and its earthy centerpiece, the handmade tortilla, has created a small but growing market for native corn.

item.title: World Briefing: Canada: Another Human Foot Washes Ashore
item.description: The foot was found by a hiker on Vancouver Island’s Botanical Beach and was the 13th to wash up on British Columbia’s shoreline since 2007.
item.dc:creator: IAN AUSTEN

item.title: Russian Intervention in Syrian War Has Sharply Reduced U.S. Options
item.description: Russian military action has changed the shape of a conflict that had effectively been stalemated for years, and suddenly, President Bashar al-Assad of Syria and his allies have momentum.
item.dc:creator: DAVID E. SANGER
item.media:description: A refugee from Syria with her grandson after entering south-central Turkey on Wednesday.

item.title: World Briefing: India: Deworming Campaign Begins
item.description: Millions of children are getting treatment in a national effort to prevent parasitic worms from infecting them and impairing their mental and physical development.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
